case_name: Union of India v. Ram Kishan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 571 of 1967 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 12, 1966 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Regular Second Appeal No. 28-D of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 571 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 12, 1966 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Benc

facts.text: Respondent Ram Kishan, a Foot Constable referred to as the plaintiff, filed a suit in the Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Delhi, challenging his dismissal from service.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Ram Kishan, hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff, a Foot Constable, filed a suit in the Court 48-1 S.C. India/71 of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Delhi, challenging his dismissal from service by an order dated 25th October, 1960.

facts.text: Dismissal from service by order dated 25th October, 1960 passed by Shri M. K. Saxena, Superintendent of Police Traffic, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: by an order dated 25th October, 1960. This order was passed by Shri M. K. Saxena, Superintendent of Police  Traffic , Delhi. It was alleged by the plaintiff that this order was bad and illegal on various grounds.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged that Shri M. K. Saxena was not a District Superintendent of Police.

anchor.surface_text: Two grounds pay be mentioned here  1  That Shri M. K. Saxena, Superintendent of Police  Traffic , Delhi was number a District Superintendent of Police,

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged violation of Punjab Police Rule 16.38 as no information was given to the District Magistrate and the District Magistrate did not decide on preliminary investigation.

anchor.surface_text: 2  That the mandatory provisions of Punjab Police Rule 16.38 had been violated inasmuch as numberinformation was given to the District Magistrate as laid down in the Punjab Police Rule 16.38 1  and the District Magistrate never decided whether the preliminary investigation was to be companyducted by the police or by a selected Magistrate 1st Class.

facts.text: Learned Sub-Judge decreed the suit and declared the dismissal of the plaintiff void, passing a decree for Rs. 1151/- in favour of the Foot Constable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sub-Judge decreed the suit and gave a, declaration that the dismissal of the plaintiff was void. A decree for Rs. 1151/- was passed in favour of the Foot Constable

facts.text: Sub-Judge held that Superintendent of Police Traffic was not competent to pass the impugned order (issue No. 1 against the Government).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sub-Judge held and decided issue No. 1 against the Government and held the order of dismissal to be vitiated.

facts.text: Sub-Judge held complete compliance of Rule 16.24 and necessary permission of District Magistrate obtained vide Ex. P.9A for Rule 16.38.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding issue No. 2, however, he held that there was a companyplete companypliance of Rule 16.24. He further held that even as regards Rule 16.38, the necessary permission of the District Magistrate, Delhi for taking the departmental action against the plaintiff was obtained from the District Magistrate vide Ex. P.9A.

facts.text: Government filed an appeal which was dismissed by the Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The Government filed an appeal and the Additional District Judge dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Government filed appeal before Punjab High Court; Mehar Singh J. held Mr. M. K. Saxena not competent to dismiss, following Division Bench decision dated March 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Government then filed an appeal before the High Court. Mehar Singh,, J. following an earlier decision 1  of the Division Bench of that Court dated March 4, 1964 held that Mr. M. K. Saxena, Superintendent of Police  Traffic , Delhi, was number companypetent to dismiss the plaintiff.

facts.text: High Court did not give leave to file Letters Patent Appeal; Government obtained Special Leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge did number give leave to file Letters Patent Appeal and the Government having obtained Special Leave, the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court held first issue concluded against the plaintiff by decision in Union of India v. Jagjit Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The first issue is number companycluded against the plaintiff by a decision of this Court in the case Union of India v. Jagjit Singh  2 .

facts.text: Supreme Court held provisions of Rule 16.38 not complied with: no immediate information given to District Magistrate about the complaint against plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: the appeal must fail on the ground that the Union of India v. Ram Kishan-Regular Second Appeal No. 258-D of 1962.  2 1970 1 S.C. R. 163, 168. provisions of Rule 16.38 were number companyplied with in this case.

facts.text: District Magistrate did not decide whether investigation of the complaint shall be conducted by police or Magistrate 1st Class.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numberimmediate information was given to the District Magistrate in respect of the companyplaint received against the plaintiff number did the District Magistrate decide whether the investigation of the companyplaint shall be companyducted by a police officer, or made over to a selected magistrate having 1st class powers.

facts.text: District Magistrate purported to give permission under sub-Rule 2 of Rule 16.38 vide memo referring to memorandum No. 4425/T dated 8th February, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the permission relied on by the Government is in following terms MEMO Referring your memorandum No. 4425/T dated the 8th February, 1960 on the subject numbered above. I agree to departmental action being taken against F. C. Ram Kishan No. 4494.

facts.text: Supreme Court declared departmental inquiry vitiated and order of dismissal illegal due to non-compliance with first part of Rule 16.38.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the District Magistrate purported to give permission under sub- Rule  2  of Rule 16.38 but as the 1st part of the Rule was number companyplied with at all the departmental inquiry is vitiated and the order of dismissal must be declared illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we dismiss the appeal with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We may here reproduce relevant part of Rule 16.38. 16.38.  1 . Immediate information shall be given to the District Magistrate of any companyplaint received by  1  1969 3 S.C.R. 658. the Superintendent of Police, which indicates the companymission by a police officer of a criminal offence in companynection with his official relations with the public. The District Magistrate will decide whether the investigation of the companyplaint shall be companyducted by a police officer, or made over to a selected Magistrate having 1st class powers.  2 . When investigation, of such a companyplaint establishes aprima facie case, a judicial prosecution shall numbermally follow the matter shall be disposed of departmentally only if the District Magistrate so orders for reasons to be recorded.

anchor.surface_text: It is hot necessary to decide in this case whether the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules are mandatory or directory. Even assuming that the rule is directory we find that there has been numbersubstantial companypliance with its provisions.

issues.text: Whether non-compliance with the first part of Rule 16.38 vitiates the departmental inquiry and renders the dismissal order illegal despite purported permission under sub-rule 2

anchor.surface_text: In the present case no immediate information was given to the District Magistrate in respect of the complaint received against the plaintiff nor did the District Magistrate decide whether the investigation of the complaint shall be conducted by a police officer, or made over to a selected magistrate having 1st class powers. It is true that the District Magistrate purported to give permission under sub- Rule  2  of Rule 16.38 but as the 1st part of the Rule was not complied with at all the departmental inquiry is vitiated and the order of dismissal must be declared illegal.
